title: Lost Copilot agent's "kept" changes after VSCode update
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0

Steps to reproduce (or just post-moretem report):
- I was working on some amount of changes since the morning.
- They were all "kept", but not commited to the git repo.
- Somewhere between 9:00 and 10:00 AM I've seen the info that I can update VSCode. There was also Copilot Chat extension update available.
- I didn't do the updates instantly because I was actively working on the feature.
- Around 1:20 PM I decided to make a VS Code update:
    - First I've updated Copilot Chat extension, everything was fine
    - I've checked the code, was 👍🏻, so I moved to the next step,
    - I did VS Code update, which is resetting the VS Code itself,
    - I was surprised, because all of my work since the morning was gone.
- ❌ Copilot history was reset to the moment it has been shortly I've started my work today,
- ❌ All changes that were "kept" were gone,
- ❌ I was not able to restore my work.
- ⚠️ I need to start over, so I lost few hours of very intensive and productive day. 🤯

❓❓❓ My question here is: could we do anything to improve this experience?

From my side I'm going to ALWAYS commit all I have before any update of VSCode or extension. However, it's not how I feel it should work. Any VSCode or Extension update shouldn't erase ones work. Never.
Maybe we could improve the UX or anything when it comes to updates?

title: Fix out of bounds text selection with line wrapping
body:
The original behaviour is confusing and somewhat hard to explain. Given a Monaco editor with text wrapping enabled, if the user starts selecting text and moves the mouse outside of the editor viewbox, to the right of the screen, the cursor in the editor would be somewhere halfway the editor. The editor cursor did move with the mouse. So moving the mouse further right, moved the cursor further forward. The text cursor could even move onto the next line, below the mouse position. In case of RTL, the behaviour was the same. Further right means more forward, meaning it was visually mirrored.

The new behaviour with this PR is easier to explain. If the cursor moves out of bounds while selecting text, the selection will match the end of the wrapped line at column matching the cursor height. It also takes RTL into account.

The new behaviour matches gedit, LibreOffice, Google Docs, HTML content in browsers, and even Monaco Editor with text wrapping disabled.

title: Improve handling of `git --no-pager`

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
We hint the agent to use `--no-pager` in the terminal tool:

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/f8e22cf5d83f4f1c9867993290fa54fc1e079457/src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminalContrib/chatAgentTools/browser/tools/runInTerminalTool.ts#L86

For `git` specifically we should instead handle this in command re-writing _after_ auto approval has succeeded to avoid it messing with our simple default git auto approvals:

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/f8e22cf5d83f4f1c9867993290fa54fc1e079457/src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminalContrib/chatAgentTools/common/terminalChatAgentToolsConfiguration.ts#L147-L150

title: The ANSI reset escape doesn't terminate an hyperlink

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Issues that have not been triaged in an appropriate amount of time

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No - VS Code Version: 1.100.0 (Universal) - OS Version: macOS Monterey Steps to Reproduce: 1. Run this: ```js // Normal style console.log ( `\x1b[31;4mred\x1b[39;24m foo` ); // Reset style console.log ( `\x1b[31;4mred\x1b[0m foo` ); // Normal hyperlink console.log ( '\x1B]8;;https://github.com\x07Click\x1B]8;;\x07 foo' ); // Reset hyperlink console.log ( '\x1B]8;;https://github.com\x07Click\x1b[0m foo' ); ``` 2. Look at the terminal: 3. Notice how we can use the reset escape sequence, `\x1b[0m`, to reset styling, but using it for the hyperlink escape sequence doesn't work. --- Should the hyperlink be terminated by the reset character too? The [spec](https://gist.github.com/egmontkob/eb114294efbcd5adb1944c9f3cb5feda) seems a bit ambiguous about this, but it does say the following: > You can practically think of the hyperlink as yet another attribute that character cells have, similarly to the foreground and background color, bold, italic, strikethrough etc. bits Which makes me think links should also be ended when the reset escape sequence is found.

title: Installing extension-based MCP server doesn't show tools
body:
When installing an extension-based MCP server from the MCP gallery page, the MCP tools are available and server doesn't start.

Environment:

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30.2
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: Windows 11
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent mode

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Stable, new window, no extensions installed
1. Extensions view > Browse MCP Servers
1. Click Install for Context7 extension
1. Click Install again in VS Code
1. Open tools picker -> tools from Context7 are not shown
1. Run **MCP: List Servers** command -> MCP server doesn't show in the list

title: Agent Mode: Command executes even after pressing Cancel (dangerous; rm -rf ran despite abort)
body: Summary: In Copilot Agent Mode, shell commands are executed even when pressing Cancel in the confirmation dialog. The UI shows the action as rejected, but the command still runs (tested with fish, reproducible 100%). This creates a high risk of unintended destructive commands (e.g. rm -rf). * **Copilot Chat Extension Version:** v0.31.2025082202 (pre-release) * **VS Code Version:** 1.104.0-insider (user setup) Commit: `2db7aa70ee3e250a2fcdb4dbbd85dd524d2fb7a2` Electron: 37.2.3 / Chromium: 138.0.7204.100 / Node.js: 22.17.0 / V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0 * **OS Version:** Windows\_NT x64 10.0.26100 (Windows 11 24H2) * **Feature:** **Agent mode** * **Selected model:** **Claude Sonnet 4** * **Reproducibility:** 100% (happens every time) * **Severity:** High (commands like `rm -rf` are executed even after pressing cancel → data loss risk) --- ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open **Agent Mode** in Copilot Chat and let it propose a terminal command (e.g. build/cleanup). 2. The dialog pops up: **“Run fish command?”** with **Continue** and **Cancel** buttons. Example command from my case: ```sh cd /var/www/thc.nurrobin.de/nextjs && rm -rf .next && npm run build --no-lint 2>&1 | head -20 ``` 3. Press **Cancel**. --- ### Actual Behavior * **The command still executes in the terminal, even after pressing Cancel.** * The UI marks the suggestion with a **“×”** (rejected), but the terminal clearly shows execution (including output and errors). See screenshots: * (dialog showing “Run fish command?” with cancel option) * (command executed despite cancel, `rm -rf` + npm build output) --- ### Expected Behavior * When pressing **Cancel**, **no command should ever be executed**. * Agent should either do nothing or log that the action was aborted. --- ### Additional Context * This issue is **independent of the specific command** – any proposed shell command will still run after pressing Cancel. * The risk is obvious: destructive commands like `rm -rf`, database resets, or production deploys could run unintentionally. * The dialog UI and the execution pipeline seem out of sync: UI shows “rejected”, but the command promise still runs. --- ### Logs / Evidence Screen-Capture of the Issue: [https://youtu.be/WoYWJQ3bC-4](https://youtu.be/WoYWJQ3bC-4) Terminal snippet (shortened): ``` Run fish command? cd /var/www/thc.nurrobin.de/nextjs && rm -rf .next && npm run build --no-lint 2>&1 | head -20 ... > next build --no-lint ⚠ Linting is disabled. ... Build error occurred [Error: EACCES: permission denied, unlink '/var/www/thc.nurrobin.de/nextjs/.next/server/app-paths-manifest.json'] ``` ### Copilot Logs ```` 2025-08-22 11:06:27.480 [info] BYOK: title: javascript debugger local file in chrome: unable to connect port 9222

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: debug
labels.description: Debug viewlet, configurations, breakpoints, adapter issues

body:
Type: Bug I get this error message when I try to start Chrome debugging on a local HTML file: "Could not connect to debug target at http://localhost:9222: Chrome could not find a debuggable target". The browser opens to about:blank. I believe the cause is that VScode isn't waiting for the Chrome process to finish starting and port 9222 isn't active yet. In fact, if I leave the browser open on about:blank and give the debug start command again, a second about:blank tab opens but the first tab updates correctly pointing to the test.html file, proving that on the second attempt the browser was listening on port 9222 while on the first attempt it was not listening yet. There's no option in launch.json that allows you to add a delay to the connection attempt to give Chrome time to start correctly. launch.json : { "name": "Launch Chrome Debug", "type": "chrome", "request": "launch", "file": "${workspaceFolder}/test.html", "webRoot": "${workspaceFolder}", "port": 9222, "sourceMaps": true, "trace": true, "userDataDir": "${workspaceFolder}/.vscode/chrome-debug", "timeout": 30000, } VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a class file through a link (e.g., navigating from a reference or symbol).
2. VS Code opens the target file.
3. The editor renders the file shifted completely to the left.

Expected Behavior
- The file should open in the editor with normal alignment and readable layout.
- User should be able to scroll or reset the view if needed.

Actual Behavior
- The file opens fully indented/shifted to the left side of the editor.
- It is not possible to return to the normal view (no scrolling or layout reset works).

title: Improve error message for Visual Studio detection in build process
body:
The VS Code build process was failing when Visual Studio was installed in custom paths instead of the default Program Files directories. The `hasSupportedVisualStudioVersion()` function in `build/npm/preinstall.js` only checked environment variables and standard installation paths, causing build failures with unhelpful error messages.

## Changes Made

### Enhanced Error Messages
When Visual Studio detection fails, users now receive clear guidance:
```
*** Invalid C/C++ Compiler Toolchain. Please check https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#prerequisites.
*** If you have Visual Studio installed in a custom location, you can specify it via the environment variable:
*** set vs2022_install=<path> (or vs2019_install, vs2017_install for older versions)
```

## Testing
The fix has been validated to:
- Provide helpful error messages for troubleshooting

This resolves build issues for developers with Visual Studio installed in custom directories while improving the developer experience with better error guidance.

Fixes #259576.

title: [prompts] One-Click install of Copilot Instructions / Prompts from private Github repos

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: chat-prompts
labels.description: Prompt and Instruction files related issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Hi VSCode Team,

We're looking to implement one-click installs for chat modes, instructions, and prompts from our private repository, similar to the functionality demonstrated in https://github.com/github/awesome-copilot.

Currently, this isn't possible because accessing raw files from private repositories via https://raw.githubusercontent.com URLs requires authentication tokens, like:

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/org/repo/refs/heads/main/instructions/org.instructions.md?token=GHSAT0AAAAAA***

**The Challenge:**
While VSCode already has excellent GitHub authentication integration for Git operations, this authentication doesn't extend to raw file access from private repositories. Users currently need to manually generate and manage Personal Access Tokens for this use case.

**Proposed Solution:**
Could VSCode leverage its existing GitHub authentication to handle token-based access to raw files from private repositories automatically? This would enable:

Seamless one-click installs from private repositories

1. Better security (no manual token management)
2. Consistent authentication experience across all GitHub integrations
3. This feature would significantly improve the developer experience for teams using private repositories for sharing VSCode configurations, extensions, and prompts.

Thank you for considering this enhancement!

Best regards,
Chris

title: Copilot stops waiting for command to finish after changing default terminal setting.

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
First of all, Copilot DOES wait for the command to finish before continuing its work. Problems arise when I go to settings and change the `terminal.integrated.defaultProfile.windows` setting from PowerShell to for example Command Prompt. When I ask copilot to run the same command again, it does not wait for it to finish anymore. Changing back to PowerShell doesn't solve the issue. Restarting VS Code solves the issue.

Problem only happens if the command takes a while to finish, such as running tests.

We should investigate if existing solutions, like https://github.com/TypeFox/monaco-languageclient , work well enough.

title: Ship Monaco Editor with only ESM support

labels.name: plan-item
labels.description: VS Code - planned item for upcoming

body:
We should release a fresh version of the Monaco Editor.

Due to VS Code's migration to ESM, the release will no longer contain the AMD variant. We need to make sure this is clearly communicated in the changelog. The only thing the ESM variant was missing before vs the AMD variant was out-of-the-box support for localization, so we should make sure to add examples and document how localization can be exercised by a consumer.

title: Editor-style text manipulation shortcuts in Copilot Chat
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
## Feature request: Editor-style text manipulation shortcuts in Copilot Chat

### Summary

Allow the chat input area in Copilot Chat to behave like a mini editor so users can use familiar editor-style text-manipulation shortcuts. Treating the chat as a tiny editor would also make it straightforward to surface suggested autocompletes (and optionally accept them) using the same editor completion suggestion APIs.

### User Story:

"As a user, I want the chat to have editor-style text manipulation shortcuts. If we just replace it with a mini editor, could suggested autocompletes also be brought over automatically or with minor API changes?

As a user, if I could treat copilot-chat as a mini editor with hidden lines, I think that would be very helpful as most of my coding is actually now done in Copilot Chat."

### Problem statement

Many users perform comples messages/prompts and refactors inside Copilot Chat. The current chat input is limited compared to the editor: lacking multi-line editing ergonomics, editor keyboard shortcuts, local autocompletion, and inline acceptance of suggestions. This slows down workflows and forces frequent context-switching between chat and the editor or increases manual typing requirement on the user.

### Proposal

- Replace or augment the chat input with a lightweight embedded editor instance that supports:
  - standard editor keyboard shortcuts ( undo/redo ✅, cut/copy/paste ✅, move line, duplicate line, indent/outdent)
  - multi-line editing with visible/hideable lines
  - inline suggestions/autocompletes surfaced from the same completion engine used in the full editor
  - default to a Markdown editing mode with syntax highlighting, soft-wrapping ✅, and optional preview 🤷‍♂️ to improve readability for chat-based code and prose
- Keep an API that allows the autocomplete component to be reused by extensions or the desktop editor, with minimal changes.

### Suggested UX/Surface

- Chat mini-editor defaults:
- Keyboard conventions (examples):
  - Cmd/Ctrl+Enter: send message ✅
  - Shift+Enter: insert newline (or expand editor) ✅
  - Tab / Shift+Tab: snippet/tab navigation or indent/outdent (configurable)
  - Ctrl+Space: trigger inline suggestions
  - Esc: blur / close suggestions
- Autocomplete:
  - reuse the same suggestion provider used by the editor
  - show inline ghost text and full suggestion UI, allow Accept (Tab)
  - 
- language: defaults to `markdown` for improved QoL in chat workflows

This API keeps the integration surface small and makes it easy for the existing completion/autocomplete systems to plug in.

### Acceptance criteria / success metrics

- Users can use common editor shortcuts inside chat without leaving the component.
- Inline completions appear and can be accepted from chat just like in the editor.

title: Integrated Terminal issue with environment variables change

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
Type: Bug If system or user environment variables are changed, all instances/windows of VSCode need to be closed for the integrated terminal to take the change into consideration. The issue is present in both VSCode stable and VSCode Insiders. The following is tested on both VSCode stable and Insiders: - The issue is present even with "--disable-extensions". - Reloading the window (">Developer: Reload Window") doesn't fix the issue. - Opening a new integrated terminal does't resolve the issue. - The issue is present for different types of shells (PowerShell, cmd, git-bash...). - Issue is still present even when running with admin privileges . - Note that if VSCode was launched from a terminal, closing all windows and relaunching from the same terminal will not resolve the issue (I guess it's because the VSCode integrated terminal inherets the environment variables from the terminal that launches it). title: Option to restore or copy deleted lines when Copilot applies changes
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, when Copilot applies code changes, it directly deletes the existing lines and replaces them with the new suggestion. This can make it difficult to recover or compare the deleted lines if the change isn’t ideal.

**Proposed Feature**

- Add a way to restore deleted lines after Copilot applies changes.
- At a minimum, provide a "copy deleted code" or "view replaced lines" option so developers can quickly reinsert or compare old code.
- This would improve safety, usability, and confidence in applying Copilot suggestions, especially for large edits.

**Benefits**

- Prevents accidental loss of code.
- Makes it easier to compare old and new code.
- Reduces friction for developers experimenting with Copilot edits.

Example Scenario

- Copilot suggests replacing 10 lines of code.
- The developer accepts the change.
- The old 10 lines are gone, with no quick way to recover them.
- A restore/copy option would let the developer bring back those lines instantly without digging into undo history.

## GitHub Tags
#A11yeDAD; #A11yMAS; #A11yTCS; #Win32; #DesktopApp; #Visual Studio Code Client; #BM-VisualStudioCodeClient-Win32-Jan2024;  #FTP; #Keyboard; #A11ySev3; #WCAG2.4.3;

## Environment Details:
Application: VS Code
Visual studio code version: 1.103.1
OS: Windows 11 Enterprise 24H2
Build: 26100.2605

## Repro Steps

1. Open Visual Studio Code 
2. Ensure GitHub Copilot is installed and signed in.
3. Open git hub copilot chat and ask copilot to write some code 
4. Now navigate to copilot response
5.  Observe the issue

## Actual Experience.
When focus is on "Configure tools" button and pressing TAB key focus moves to "MCP server" control but focus is not visible only tool tip is visible and pressing TAB key again focus will visible on same control and now using arrow key only we will be able to move away from "MCP server" control,
but when focus is on "Configure tools" button and pressing arrow key focus navigation is correct.

## Expected Experience
"MCP server" control  should not be accessible using TAB key. When focus is on "Configure tools" button and pressing TAB key focus should move to notification bar.

## User Impact:
Keyboard only user face difficulty as focus is not visible first time and than user is not able move away using TAB/Shift + TAB key.

#A11yeDAD; #A11ySev2; #A11yTCS; #Win32; #DesktopApp; #Visual Studio Code Client; #BM-VisualStudioCodeClient-Win32-Jan2024;  #FTP; #Keyboard; #MAS2.4.3;

## Environment Details:
Application: VS Code
Visual studio code version: 1.103.1
OS: Windows 11 Enterprise 24H2
Build: 26100.2605

## Repro Steps

1. Open Visual Studio Code 
2. Ensure GitHub Copilot is installed and signed in.
3. Open git hub copilot chat and ask copilot to write some code 
4. Now navigate to copilot response
5.  Observe the issue

## Actual Experience.
To switch between messages on the chat board using the up and down arrow keys, you first need to navigate through all interactive controls in the latest Copilot response by pressing Shift + Tab.

When keyboard focus is on "Add context" button and pressing Shift + Tab key, keyboard focus should move to whole copilot response than using up/down arrow key user can switch between messages and by pressing TAB key user move inside the copilot response.

## User Impact:
Keyboard only user will face difficulty if they want to move any old response or prompt on the chat board first they need to navigate through all interactive control of latest Copilot response by pressing Shift + Tab than only they can move with up and down arrow key.

title: Merge editor fails to find edited-&-renamed files

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
Type: Bug Steps to Reproduce 1. Initialize an empty Git repository, add a file with a single line of text, and make an initial commit 2. Edit that line of text and make a second commit (on branch `main`) 3. Branching off of the initial commit (branch name `rename`), make a third commit that edits that same line of text but also renames the file At this point the commit history should look like ``` Edit the line o ------------------o (main) Initial commit \ -----------o (rename) Edit the line AND rename the file ``` 4. Attempt to merge `rename` into `main`. This will cause a merge conflict. Expected result: This merge conflict can be resolved in the merge editor ("Resolve in Merge Editor"). title: Copilot Pro 30-Day Trial Active but VS Code Still Shows Free Tier Quota
body:
Type: Bug I subscribed to the GitHub Copilot Pro 30-day free trial, and my billing settings confirm that the trial is active (next billing date is September 20, 2025). However, in Visual Studio Code, when I try to use Copilot Chat, I receive the error: "You've reached your monthly chat messages quota. Upgrade to Copilot Pro (30-day free trial) or wait for your allowance to renew." This suggests that my Pro trial is not being recognized in VS Code, even though it is active on my GitHub account. title: Copilot goes "Great! The build succeeded" when the build task was still running and had barely even started

labels.name: *duplicate

title: Running "Move Editor into Previous Group" from the left-most group should create a new group to the left.

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: workbench-editor-groups
labels.description: Issues related to editor groups

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, when the active editor is in the left-most editor group and I run the command "Move Editor into Previous Group," nothing happens because there is no group further left.

I would like this command to instead create a new editor group on the left and move the active editor into it, pushing the existing groups to the right. This would somewhat mirror the existing behavior of "Move Editor into Next Group," which creates a new group when invoked from the right-most editor group.

Stipulation:
This should only occur if there are two or more editors open in the left-most group.
If there is only a single editor in the left-most group, the command should continue to do nothing,
to avoid leaving the group empty.

Justification:
If I want to place an editor in the left-most position, I currently have to move it into
the existing left-most group and then manually shift other editors to the right.
This is tedious and interrupts workflow. Having "Move Editor into Previous Group" automatically
create a new left-most group (when more than one editor is present) would make arranging editors
much easier and more consistent.

I don’t know if there’s an easier way to accomplish this task visually, but I am blind and
use a screen reader.

title: GitHub Copilot Chat: Allow resizing file reference list to reclaim conversation space
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

**Feature Request: Add Resizable File Reference Lists in Chat UI**

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30.2
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2 (user setup)
- OS Version: Windows 11 (ARM64)
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Chat UI (all modes)
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude 3.5 Sonnet
- Logs: N/A (Feature Request)

## Problem Description

When there are many file attachments (e.g., 6+ files as shown in the screenshot below), the reference list at the bottom of chat responses consumes approximately 25-30% of the chat panel height, significantly reducing the space available for conversation content. Currently, users have no control over this space allocation.

![Screenshot showing file reference list taking up significant space](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9153f314-3768-4d82-b70a-fbeccb368854)

## Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open GitHub Copilot Chat in VS Code
2. Create a chat session that references multiple files (6+ files)
3. Observe that the file reference list at the bottom takes up ~25-30% of chat panel height
4. Note there is no way to resize or minimize this list to reclaim space for conversation content

## Current Behavior

- File references are displayed in a fixed-height scrollable list
- The list shows a subset of files (scrollable to see more)
- Takes up significant visual real estate with no user control
- Users cannot adjust the balance between conversation and reference viewing space
- Only workaround is resizing the entire chat panel, which affects all content

## Expected Behavior

Users should be able to:
- Drag a resize handle between chat content and reference list to adjust proportions
- Have their preferred size remembered between sessions
- Quickly switch between preset sizes (minimize/compact/default/expanded)
- Control space allocation based on current workflow needs

## Proposed Solution

### Primary: Resizable Reference Panel
- Add a **draggable resize handle** between the chat content and the reference list
- Allow users to drag to resize the reference list area up/down
- **Persist the user's preferred height** between sessions
- Set reasonable min/max constraints (e.g., minimum 2 lines, maximum 50% of chat height)

### Visual Design Concept
```
┌─────────────────────────────────┐
│ Chat conversation content       │
│ ...                            │
│ Let's start fresh! I'll run... │
├═════════════════════════════════┤ ← Draggable resize handle
│ ▼ Used 14 references           │
│ 📄 copilotdemo-sql-resources...│
│ 📄 deploy.ps1                 │
│ 📄 dev.parameters.json        │
│ ...                            │
└─────────────────────────────────┘
```

### Secondary: Quick Size Presets
- Add context menu or icon buttons for quick presets:
  - "Minimize" - Show only header line with file count
  - "Compact" - Show 2-3 file lines
  - "Default" - Current behavior
  - "Expanded" - Larger view for detailed file review

## Suggested Configuration Options

```json
{
  "github.copilot.chat.references.defaultHeight": {
    "type": "number",
    "default": 120,
    "description": "Default height in pixels for the file reference list area"
  },
  "github.copilot.chat.references.rememberSize": {
    "type": "boolean",
    "default": true,
    "description": "Remember the user's preferred reference list size between sessions"
  },
  "github.copilot.chat.references.maxHeightPercent": {
    "type": "number",
    "default": 50,
    "minimum": 20,
    "maximum": 80,
    "description": "Maximum percentage of chat panel height that references can occupy"
  }
}
```

## Benefits

- **User control** - Each user can set their preferred balance between conversation and reference viewing
- **Contextual flexibility** - Resize based on current task (large when reviewing many files, small when focusing on conversation)
- **Persistent preferences** - Saves user's preferred size for consistent experience
- **Progressive disclosure** - Can minimize when not needed, expand when file details are important
- **Backwards compatible** - Default behavior unchanged for users who don't interact with resize
- **Follows VS Code patterns** - Consistent with existing resizable panels (Terminal, Problems, Explorer sections)

## Implementation Areas

This would likely require:
- VS Code chat UI rendering modifications (core VS Code changes)
- State persistence for user preferences
- Resize handle implementation in chat response rendering
- Configuration schema updates

## Similar Patterns in VS Code

This follows established VS Code patterns:
- **Panel resizing** - Terminal, Problems, Output panels are all resizable
- **Explorer sections** - File explorer sections can be resized
- **Editor groups** - Split editor panes are resizable
- **Sidebar panels** - Extension views often have resizable sections

## Use Cases

This would significantly improve workflows involving:
- Large refactoring projects with many file changes
- Project setup and scaffolding
- Comprehensive code reviews
- Multi-file debugging sessions
- Any scenario where users need to balance conversation reading with file reference review

## Additional Context

The current fixed-height approach works well for small numbers of files, but becomes problematic when working with larger file sets. A resizable approach would provide the flexibility needed for different user preferences and use cases while maintaining the current default experience for users who don't need to adjust it.

title: Allow modals in automation
body:
This allows for the opt-in behavior of allowing dialogs while using automation. I went with opt-in to reduce the blast radius (our smoke tests assume dialogs don't show).

When opted in, we also switch over to using custom dialogs & the simple file picker so that the automation can control it.

This was added so that we can do auth flows, which uses dialogs. Now we will be able to complete an auth flow (with the help of the user in the browser) and automate interacting with chat via the development MCP server.
